abstract.text: Customize your app’s user interface with views and controls.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: UIKit Catalog: Creating and customizing views and controls

inlineContent.text: This sample guides you through several types of customizations you can make in your iOS app. It is built with Mac Catalyst, which means the sample runs on both iOS and macOS. The sample uses a split-view controller architecture to navigate UIKit views and controls. The primary view controller (
) shows the available views and controls. When you select one,
shows the secondary view controller associated with it.
The name of each secondary view controller reflects its target item. For example, the
class shows how to use a
object. The only exceptions to this rule are
and

; the sample demonstrates these APIs in multiple view controllers to explain how their controls function and how to customize them. To demonstrate how to manage the complexity of your storyboards, the app hosts all view controllers in a separate storyboard and loads each as it’s when needed.
This sample demonstrates the following views and controls; several of which are referenced in the sections below:
In Xcode, select your development team on the iOS-Mac target’s Signing and Capabilities tab.

content.text: Customize the look of buttons with button configurations

inlineContent.text: You can customize the appearance and behavior of a UIButton by using
. This sample uses a
configuration so that the button draws with a red background color:
demonstrates several techniques to display modal alerts and action sheets from an interface. The configuration process is similar for all alerts:
Determine the message to display in the alert.
Create and configure a
object.
Add handlers for actions the user may take.
Present the alert controller.
The
function uses the
function to retrieve the alert messages in the user’s preferred language. The
function uses those strings to create and configure the
object. Although the button in the alert has the title OK, the sample uses a cancel action to ensure that the alert controller applies the proper styling to the button:

code: let title = NSLocalizedString("A Short Title is Best", comment: "")
let message = NSLocalizedString("A message needs to be a short, complete sentence.", comment: "")
let alertController = UIAlertController(title: title, message: message, preferredStyle: .alert)

inlineContent.text: This sample demonstrates different ways to display a

, a control to select a single value from a continuous range of values. Customize the appearance of a slider by assigning stretchable images for left-side tracking, right-side tracking, and the thumb. In this example, the track image is stretchable and is one pixel wide. Make the track images wider to provide rounded corners, but be sure to set these images’
property to allow for the corners.
The
function sets up a custom slider:

code: /** To keep the look the same betwen iOS and macOS:
For setMinimumTrackImage, setMaximumTrackImage, setThumbImage to work in Mac Catalyst, use UIBehavioralStyle as ".pad",
Available in macOS 12 or later (Mac Catalyst 15.0 or later).
Use this for controls that need to look the same between iOS and macOS.
// Set the sliding thumb image (normal and highlighted).
// For fun, choose a different image symbol configuraton for the thumb's image between macOS and iOS.
// Set the rest of the slider's attributes.

content.text: Add a search bar to an interface

inlineContent.text: Use a
to receive search-related information from the user. There are various ways to customize the look of the search bar:
Add a cancel button.
Add a bookmark button.
Set the bookmark image, both normal and highlighted states.
Change the tint color that applies to key elements in the search bar.
Set the search bar’s background image.
The
function sets up a custom search bar:

code: // Set the bookmark image for both normal and highlighted states.

inlineContent.text: demonstrates further customization by changing the toolbar’s background image:
Use a
to structure an app’s user interface. A
page control

is a specialized control that displays a horizontal series of dots, each of which corresponds to a page in the app’s document or other data-model entity. Customize a page control by setting its tint color for all the page-indicator dots, and for the current page-indicator dot.
The
function sets up a customized page control:

code: // The total number of available pages is based on the number of available colors.

content.text: Add accessibility support to your views

inlineContent.text: VoiceOver and other system accessibility technologies use the information provided by views and controls to help all users navigate content. UIKit views include default accessibility support. Improve user experience by providing custom accessibility information.
In this UIKitCatalog sample, several view controllers configure the
and
properties of their associated view. Picker view columns don’t have labels, so the picker view asks its delegate for the corresponding accessibility information:

code: func pickerView(_ pickerView: UIPickerView, accessibilityLabelForComponent component: Int) -> String? {
return NSLocalizedString("Red color component value", comment: "")
return NSLocalizedString("Green color component value", comment: "")
return NSLocalizedString("Blue color component value", comment: "")

inlineContent.text: This sample app is built with Mac Catalyst, which means the sample runs on both iOS and Mac. This is achieved by selecting the Mac checkbox in Project Settings. For more about how Mac Catalyst works see
When built for Mac Catalyst, this sample achieves:

Interface Optimization for Mac. With Optimize Interface For the Mac project setting turned on, the app has full control of every pixel on the screen, and the app can adopt more controls specific to Mac. Building the sample for Mac Catalyst makes the app take advantage of the system features in macOS.  The option Show Designed for iPad Run Destination allows this sample, as an iPad app, to run as-is on Apple silicon Macs. This requires macOS 11 and a Mac with Apple silicon.
Navigation and title bar hiding. The sample app hides these to make the app appear more like a Mac app. It also changes other behaviors by using traitCollection’s
Translucent background. By setting the split view controller’s
to
, the primary view controller or side bar shows a blurred desktop behind its view. Setting this property has no effect when running on iOS.

abstract.text: Display interactive content and controls in the Touch Bar.
An object that displays interactive web content, such as for an in-app browser.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A menu element that performs its action in a closure.
A view that shows that a task is in progress.
An object that displays an alert message.
A control that executes your custom code in response to user interactions.
A type alias defining a closure that returns a pointer style to apply to a button.
A view controller that manages the interface for selecting a color.
A control that displays a color picker.
A control for inputting date and time values.
A view controller that manages the interface for selecting a font that the system provides or the user installs.
A view controller that manages the system interfaces for taking pictures, recording movies, and choosing items from the user’s media library.
A view that displays a single image or a sequence of animated images in your interface.
A container for grouping related menu elements in an app menu or contextual menu.
A control that displays a horizontal series of dots, each of which corresponds to a page in the app’s document or other data-model entity.
A view that uses a spinning-wheel or slot-machine metaphor to show one or more sets of values.
A view that depicts the progress of a task over time.
A specialized view for receiving search-related information from the user.
A horizontal control that consists of multiple segments, each segment functioning as a discrete button.
A control for selecting a single value from a continuous range of values.
A streamlined interface for laying out a collection of views in either a column or a row.
A control for incrementing or decrementing a value.
A control that offers a binary choice, such as on/off.
An object that displays an editable text area in your interface.
An object that coordinates text formatting using the standard Mac font panel.
A scrollable, multiline text region.
A control that displays one or more buttons along the bottom edge of your interface.
An initializer for visual effect views and blur and vibrancy effect objects.
Improve your iPadOS app with Mac Catalyst by supporting native controls, multiple windows, sharing, printing, menus and keyboard shortcuts.

abstract.text: Create a version of your iPad app that users can run on a Mac device.
Display content that fills the entire height of a window by removing the title bar.

abstract.text: Provide a space for controls under a window’s title bar and above your custom content.
Manage your interface using view controllers and facilitate navigation around your app’s content.
Present your content onscreen and define the interactions allowed with that content.
